title: Little, Few, Likely, Long | Grammar Exercise

questions.question: Are you ………………………….. to be staying in this evening?
questions.description: Be likely can be followed by a to-infinitive. Probable is not used in this way.

questions.question: It is likely …………………………….
questions.description: When ‘it’ is the subject, be likely is usually followed by a that-clause.
answers: for the meeting to be postponed
that the meeting will be postponed

questions.question: ……………………….. politicians are really honest.
questions.description: We use few with plural nouns and little with uncountable nouns.

questions.question: Could I try ……………………… soup?
questions.description: Little has a rather negative meaning. A little is closer to some.

questions.question: Only …………………………. my students like mathematics.
questions.description: We use few of before a noun with a determiner.

questions.question: …………………….. people can claim that they always tell the truth.
questions.description: Before a noun without a determiner, we use few.

questions.question: …………………………. us can claim that we always tell the truth.
questions.description: Before a pronoun we use few of.

questions.question: Could I have a …………………………. the soup?
questions.description: Before a noun with a determiner, we use little of.

questions.question: You don’t need to go shopping. We have got …………………. bacon.
questions.description: A little is similar to some. Little has a negative meaning. It means almost nothing.

questions.question: The movie was ………………………… interesting
questions.description: We cannot use little to modify other adjectives or adverbs.

questions.question: She seldom stays ………………………
questions.description: In questions and negatives we usually use long.

questions.question: We have been waiting ………………………..
questions.description: In affirmative clauses, we usually prefer for a long time.
